Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Survey for Multiplicity of Low-mass (Class M) Dwarf Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project will use imaging and spectrophotometry to study 2,000 of the nearest stars. The high spatial resolution images will be capable of revealing bound planets. The spectrophotometry will provide information about the systems? temperatures and orbital characteristics. The work will focus on a type of star called M-dwarfs, which are cooler and less massive than the Sun. These stars are also considered more likely to have rocky planets habitable to life than stars like the Sun. Observations will be made with two telescopes in Arizona and one in California. Scientific results will be incorporated into an outreach program with the Discovery Channel. Students from Northern Arizona University and Southern Connecticut State University will participate in the research.

The team will use the Differential Speckle Survey Instrument (DSSI) on Lowell Observatory 4.5m telescope and the R=600 visible-light multi-object spectrophotometer on Lowell?s 31-inch telescope. Through the comparison of speckle patterns simultaneously observed at two wavelengths, DSSI can measure separations of companions below the diffraction limit. Follow-up spectrophotometry will provide data for stellar characterization and spectral energy distribution fitting. The team will also use the Palomar 200-inch telescope to assess bound companions using data from an infrared camera or optical integral field spectrometer and isochrone modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied how often the lowest-mass stars in the Solar neighborhood are found in pairs and small groups. It used an innovative imaging camera known as the Differential Speckle Survey Instrument (DSSI), which was built at Southern Connecticut State University and funded through a previous NSF award. DSSI was combined with Lowell Observatory's 4.3-m Discovery Channel Telescope (DCT) to take images of low-mass stars at extremely high resolution. In the images, close companion stars are revealed that cannot be seen with standard astronomical imaging techniques. A large sample of these stars was surveyed to give good statistics of the frequency of binaries and multiple stars in the sample as well as the properties of the companion stars.

Intellectual Merit: The results of the survey indicate that low mass stars form in pairs and multiple star systems at a lower rate than for Sun-like stars. Surveys of this nature impact astrophysics broadly, affecting our understanding of how stars form, along with their planets, and how they interact with other stars in this region of the Milky Way Galaxy. Areas of particular interest impacted by these results are exoplanet detection and formation theory, star formation, and upcoming space missions such as TESS, JWST and Gaia. The homogeneous, detailed inventory of all the nearby M-dwarfs created by the project will be a resource for many years to come.

Broader Impacts: The award partially supported three master's-level applied physics graduate students at Southern Connecticut State University, two of whom are non-traditional students who have returned to the university setting after several years working in the "blue collar" Connecticut economy. Upon graduating, they will be able to compete for jobs in the high-technology sector. The project also enabled education and public outreach activities at Southern Connecticut State University, including participation in activities for high school students organized through the STEM office at SCSU, work to repair the dome of the existing campus observatory, and the development of other public outreach resources for astronomy on campus.
